headline: It's honestly kind of strange that the conventional wisdom is "you don't need types for one-off scripts"

markdown.content:
I get the idea but just think about what your average shell script does. 
It usually runs through a list of commands, often taking several seconds, minutes or even hours, while setting up tons of imperative state on your system that is hard/annoying to undo.
These are exactly the kinds of tasks that I *want* to go right on the first try, much more so than most larger systems even.
Trying to restart a half-finished script that failed *somewhere* after half an hour, just because you messed up something simple is a terrible experience.
